param.doc: The name for the list.

param.name: mode
param.doc: Whether your list is public or private. Values can be public or private. If no mode is specified the list will be public.

param.name: description
param.doc: The description to give the list.

method.name: DELETE
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by POST lists/destroy. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Deletes the specified list. Must be owned by the authenticated user. Usage Note: clients who can not issue DELETE requests can POST with the added parameter _method=DELETE.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: id
param.doc: The ID or screen name of the user for whom to query.

param.name: list_id
param.doc: The id or slug of the list.

param.name: user
param.doc: The ID or screen name of the user for whom to return results for.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See "https://dev.twitter.com/pages/tweet_entities" for more detail on entities.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET lists/members/show. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Check if a user is a member of the specified list. Returns the user indicated by :id if the user is a member of the list.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: user
param.doc: The user id of the list member.

param.name: list_id
param.doc: The id or slug of the list.

param.name: id
param.doc: The user id of the list subscriber.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See "https://dev.twitter.com/pages/tweet_entities" for more detail on entities.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET lists/subscribers/show. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Check if a user is a subscriber of the specified list.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: user
param.doc: The user id of the list member.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET lists. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. List the lists of the specified user. Private lists will be included if the authenticated users is the same as the user who's lists are being returned.

param.name: cursor
param.doc: Breaks the results into pages. A single page contains 20 lists. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body's next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list.

method.name: POST
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by POST lists/create. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Creates a new list for the authenticated user. Accounts are limited to 20 lists.

param.name: name
param.doc: The name for the list.

param.name: description
param.doc: The description to give the list.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: user
param.doc: The user id of the list member.

param.name: list_id
param.doc: The id or slug of the list.

param.name: since_id
param.doc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

param.name: max_id
param.doc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.

param.name: per_page
param.doc: Specifies the page of results to retrieve.

param.name: page
param.doc: Specifies the page of results to retrieve.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See "https://dev.twitter.com/pages/tweet_entities" for more detail on entities.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET lists/statuses. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Show the tweet timeline for members of the specified list.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: user
param.doc: The user id of the list member.

param.name: cursor
param.doc: Breaks the results into pages. A single page contains 20 lists. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body's next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET lists/memberships. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. List the lists the specified user has been added to.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: user
param.doc: The user id of the list member.

param.name: cursor
param.doc: Breaks the results into pages. A single page contains 20 lists. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body's next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET lists/subscriptions. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. List the lists the specified user follows.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by geo/search. Please update your applications with the new endpoint.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: user_id
param.doc: The ID of the user for whom to return results for. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

param.name: screen_name
param.doc: The screen name of the potentially blocked user. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

param.name: cursor
param.doc: Breaks the results into pages. This is recommended for users who are following many users. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body's next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See "https://dev.twitter.com/pages/tweet_entities" for more detail on entities.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated as it will only return information about users who have Tweeted recently. It is not a functional way to retrieve all of a users followers. Instead of using this method use a combination of GET followers/ids and GET users/lookup. Returns the authenticating user's followers, each with current status inline. They are ordered by the order in which they followed the user, 100 at a time. (Please note that the result set isn't guaranteed to be 100 every time as suspended users will be filtered out.) Use the cursor parameter to access earlier followers. Instead of using this method to analyze a user's followers, consider using a combination of followers/ids and users/lookup instead.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: user_id
param.doc: The ID of the user for whom to return results for. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid user ID is also a valid screen name.

param.name: screen_name
param.doc: The screen name of the potentially blocked user. Helpful for disambiguating when a valid screen name is also a user ID.

param.name: cursor
param.doc: Breaks the results into pages. This is recommended for users who are following many users. Provide a value of -1 to begin paging. Provide values as returned in the response body's next_cursor and previous_cursor attributes to page back and forth in the list.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See "https://dev.twitter.com/pages/tweet_entities" for more detail on entities.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated as it will only return information about users who have Tweeted recently. It is not a functional way to retrieve all of a users followers. Instead of using this method use a combination of GET friends/ids and GET users/lookup. Returns a user's friends, each with current status inline. They are ordered by the order in which the user followed them, most recently followed first, 100 at a time. (Please note that the result set isn't guaranteed to be 100 every time as suspended users will be filtered out.) Use the cursor option to access older friends. With no user specified, request defaults to the authenticated user's friends. It is also possible to request another user's friends list via the id, screen_name or user_id parameter.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: count
param.doc: Specifies the number of records to retrieve. Must be less than or equal to 200.

param.name: since_id
param.doc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

param.name: max_id
param.doc: Returns results with an ID less than (that is, older than) or equal to the specified ID.

param.name: page
param.doc: Specifies the page of results to retrieve.

param.name: trim_user
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet returned in a timeline will include a user object including only the status authors numerical ID. Omit this parameter to receive the complete user object.

param.name: include_rts
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1,the timeline will contain native retweets (if they exist) in addition to the standard stream of tweets. The output format of retweeted tweets is identical to the representation you see in home_timeline. Note: If you're using the trim_user parameter in conjunction with include_rts, the retweets will still contain a full user object.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See "https://dev.twitter.com/pages/tweet_entities" for more detail on entities.

param.name: exclude_replies
param.doc: This parameter will prevent replies from appearing in the returned timeline. Using exclude_replies with the count parameter will mean you will receive up-to count tweets — this is because the count parameter retrieves that many tweets before filtering out retweets and replies.

param.name: contributor_details
param.doc: This parameter enhances the contributors element of the status response to include the screen_name of the contributor. By default only the user_id of the contributor is included.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET statuses/home_timeline. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Returns the 20 most recent statuses posted by the authenticating user and the user's they follow. This is the same timeline seen by a user when they login to twitter.com. This method is identical to statuses/home_timeline, except that this method will only include retweets if the include_rts parameter is set. The RSS and Atom responses will always include retweets as statuses prefixed with RT. This method can only return up to 800 statuses. If include_rts is set only 800 statuses, including retweets if they exist, can be returned.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET trends/:woeid. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Returns the top ten topics that are currently trending on Twitter. The response includes the time of the request, the name of each trend, and the url to the Twitter Search results page for that topic.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: exclude
param.doc: Setting this equal to hashtags will remove all hashtags from the trends list.

method.name: GET
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by GET trends/:woeid. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Returns the current top 10 trending topics on Twitter. The response includes the time of the request, the name of each trending topic, and query used on Twitter Search results page for that topic. It is recommended to use authentication with this method.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: user_id
param.doc: A comma separated list of user IDs, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

param.name: screen_name
param.doc: A comma separated list of screen names, up to 100 are allowed in a single request.

method.name: POST
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by POST lists/members/create_all. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Adds multiple members to a list, by specifying a comma-separated list of member ids or screen names. The authenticated user must own the list to be able to add members to it. Lists are limited to having 500 members, and you are limited to adding up to 100 members to a list at a time with this method.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: device
param.doc: Must be one of: sms, none.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See Tweet Entities for more detail on entities.

method.name: POST
method.doc: Sets which device Twitter delivers updates to for the authenticating user. Sending none as the device parameter will disable SMS updates.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: location
param.doc: The city or country describing where the user of the account is located. The contents are not normalized or geocoded in any way. Maximum of 30 characters.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discreet structure, including: user_mentions, urls, and hashtags. While entities are opt-in on timelines at present, they will be made a default component of output in the future. See "https://dev.twitter.com/pages/tweet_entities" for more details.

param.name: skip_status
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1 statuses will not be included in the returned user objects.

method.name: POST
method.doc: This method is deprecated and has been replaced by POST account/update_profile. Please update your applications with the new endpoint. Sets the value of the profile location field for the authenticating user.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: status
param.doc: The text of your status update. URL encode as necessary. t.co link wrapping (https://dev.twitter.com/docs/tco-link-wrapper/faq) may affect character counts if the post contains URLs. You must additionally account for the characters_reserved_per_media per uploaded media, additionally accounting for space characters in between finalized URLs. Note: Request the GET help/configuration (https://dev.twitter.com/docs/api/1/get/help/configuration) endpoint to get the current characters_reserved_per_media and max_media_per_upload values.

param.name: media
param.doc: Up to max_media_per_upload files may be specified in the request, each named media[]. Supported image formats are PNG, JPG and GIF. Animated GIFs are not supported. Note: Request the GET help/configuration (https://dev.twitter.com/docs/api/1/get/help/configuration) endpoint to get the current max_media_per_upload and photo_size_limit values.

param.name: possibly_sensitive
param.doc: Set to true for content which may not be suitable for every audience.

param.name: in_reply_to_status_id
param.doc: The ID of an existing status that the update is in reply to. Note: This parameter will be ignored unless the author of the tweet this parameter references is mentioned within the status text. Therefore, you must include @username, where username is the author of the referenced tweet, within the update.

param.name: lat
param.doc: The latitude of the location this tweet refers to. This parameter will be ignored unless it is inside the range -90.0 to +90.0 (North is positive) inclusive. It will also be ignored if there isn't a corresponding long parameter. Example value: 37.7821120598956.

param.name: long
param.doc: The longitude of the location this tweet refers to. The valid ranges for longitude is -180.0 to +180.0 (East is positive) inclusive. This parameter will be ignored if outside that range, not a number, geo_enabled is disabled, or if there not a corresponding lat parameter. Example value: -122.400612831116.

param.name: place_id
param.doc: A place in the world identified by a Twitter place ID. Place IDs can be retrieved from geo/reverse_geocode.

param.name: display_coordinates
param.doc: Whether or not to put a pin on the exact coordinates a tweet has been sent from.

method.name: POST
method.doc: Updates the authenticating user's status and attaches media for upload. Unlike POST statuses/update (https://dev.twitter.com/docs/api/1/post/statuses/update), this method expects raw multipart data. Your POST request's Content-Type should be set to multipart/form-data with the media[] parameter. The Tweet text will be rewritten to include the media URL(s), which will reduce the number of characters allowed in the Tweet text. If the URL(s) cannot be appended without text truncation, the tweet will be rejected and this method will return an HTTP 403 error. Important: Make sure that you're using upload.twitter.com as your host while posting statuses with media. It is strongly recommended to use SSL with this method.

param.name: Content-Type
param.doc: Content type.

param.name: format
param.doc: Response format.

param.name: q
param.doc: Search query. Should be URL encoded. Queries will be limited by complexity.

param.name: callback
param.doc: Only available for JSON format. If supplied, the response will use the JSONP format with a callback of the given name.

param.name: geocode
param.doc: Returns tweets by users located within a given radius of the given latitude/longitude. The location is preferentially taking from the Geotagging API, but will fall back to their Twitter profile. The parameter value is specified by "latitude,longitude,radius", where radius units must be specified as either "mi" (miles) or "km" (kilometers). Note that you cannot use the near operator via the API to geocode arbitrary locations; however you can use this geocode parameter to search near geocodes directly. Example value: 37.781157,-122.398720,1mi.

param.name: lang
param.doc: Restricts tweets to the given language, given by an ISO 639-1 code.

param.name: locale
param.doc: Specify the language of the query you are sending (only ja is currently effective). This is intended for language-specific clients and the default should work in the majority of cases. Example value: ja.

param.name: page
param.doc: The page number (starting at 1) to return, up to a max of roughly 1500 results (based on rpp * page).

param.name: result_type
param.doc: Specifies what type of search results you would prefer to receive. The current default is "mixed". Valid values include: - mixed: Include both popular and real time results in the response. - recent: Return only the most recent results in the response. - popular: Return only the most popular results in the response.

param.name: rpp
param.doc: The number of tweets to return per page, up to a max of 100.

param.name: show_user
param.doc: When true, prepends ":" to the beginning of the tweet. This is useful for readers that do not display Atom's author field. The default is false.

param.name: until
param.doc: Optional. Returns tweets generated before the given date. Date should be formatted as YYYY-MM-DD. Example value: 2010-03-28.

param.name: since_id
param.doc: Returns results with an ID greater than (that is, more recent than) the specified ID. There are limits to the number of Tweets which can be accessed through the API. If the limit of Tweets has occured since the since_id, the since_id will be forced to the oldest ID available.

param.name: include_entities
param.doc: When set to either true, t or 1, each tweet will include a node called "entities,". This node offers a variety of metadata about the tweet in a discrete structure, including: urls, media and hashtags. Note that user mentions are currently not supported for search and there will be no "user_mentions" key in the entities map. See Tweet Entities (https://dev.twitter.com/pages/tweet_entities) for more detail on entities. Please note that entities are only available for JSON responses in the Search API.

method.name: GET
method.doc: Returns tweets that match a specified query. To best learn how to use Twitter Search effectively, consult our guide to Using the Twitter Search API (https://dev.twitter.com/docs/using-search). Notice: As of April 1st 2010, the Search API provides an option to retrieve "popular tweets" in addition to real-time search results. In an upcoming release, this will become the default and clients that don't want to receive popular tweets in their search results will have to explicitly opt-out. See the result_type parameter below for more information. As of Nov 7, 2011 the Search API returns Twitter user IDs that match the Twitter REST API. You no longer need to maintain multiple ids for the same user. As of Dec, 2011 the Search API now supports all Tweet Entities (https://dev.twitter.com/docs/tweet-entities) when using the include_entities=true parameter.
